Title:
Genotypic and phenotypic characterization of potential
bacterial entomopathogens isolated from grasshoppers species
(Orthoptera: Acrididae)
Abstract:
Of the bacteria pathogenic to insects, the spore-forming
bacilli are viewed as having the highest potential for use in the
management of insect pest populations, and these organisms have received
the greatest commercial attention. On the other hand, B. thuringiensis
rarely induces epizootics except in cases where insects are in confined
or crowded areas such as bee hives, insect-rearing facilities, or stored
grain bins. This might account for the fact that of the few strains of
Bt selected with activity against grasshoppers, all have been isolated
from soils and no attempt to isolate Bacillus thuringiensis from
grasshoppers has yet been published. Among the Enterobacteriaceae,
Serratia spp. and Yersinia spp. have been used for the control of insect
pests. Similarly to Bacillus spp., there is no report of isolates of
these genera isolated from grasshoppers. A strain of Yersinia sp. named
MH96 was obtained from soil in New Zealand and showed activity against
the first instar larva of L. migratoria. Although Serratia spp. have
been isolated from grasshoppers, their pathogenicity has not been
further studied.
